Award.AwardTitle: Discovering and Characterizing Protoplanetary Systems Using Novel Imaging Techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stephanie Sallum is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of California, Santa Cruz. Sallum will develop methods to take the sharpest possible images of dusty disks around nearby stars. Because these disks are potential birthplaces of planets, the images will allow astronomers to understand how planets form around stars. Alongside this research, Sallum will develop an astronomy course for inmate education.

Understanding how planets form requires direct observations of accreting protoplanets. By developing and refining new imaging methods that can detect companions at a telescope's theoretical resolution limit, Sallum will advance high contrast imaging techniques to study protoplanetary disks. She will then apply these techniques to ground-based observations of protoplanetary disks containing inner clearings that might indicate the presence of accreting planets. Sallum will also prepare for future planet searches with the James Webb Space Telescope, which can detect close-in planetary companions around stars that are orders of magnitude fainter than those observable from ground-based telescopes. For the educational component of her work, Sallum will create and teach an astronomy course at the UC Santa Cruz Program for Inmate Education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to further our understanding of planet formation by carrying out high-resolution observations of young stars, and by developing techniques that will enable better characterization of these systems in the future. During this work, we observed several young stars surrounded by protoplanetary disks (disks of gas and dust left over after the star formation process). Called transition disks, these protoplanetary disks are a specific subset that have inner clearings that may be explained by young planets sweeping out material as they orbit the star. 

Using the Keck telescopes, we detected and monitored planet candidates in these objects, and also characterized complex protoplanetary disk structure at tighter orbital separations than previous studies. For non-detections, we placed deep limits on the planets that could be present in these objects. This has allowed us to work toward a statistical understanding of the planet population in transition disks. 

As part of this project, we tested different high-resolution imaging techniques to determine which ones are optimal for different observing setups. We compared the technique of non-redundant masking, which uses a mask to turn a conventional telescope into an array of smaller ones, to filled-aperture kernel phase, which involves treating a conventional telescope as if it were a large collection of smaller ones. We found that kernel phase provides the same resolution as masking for setups with low levels of aberration, making it an ideal technique for space-based observing (e.g. JWST) and/or telescopes with extreme adaptive optics correction. We tested kernel phase calibration methods and found that using wavelength information improved the calibration significantly. 

Over the course of this award, we taught pre-algebra, algebra, and astronomy to inmates at the Santa Cruz County Jail, through the Project for Inmate Education (PIE). We renewed our ability to award college credit through UC Extension to students who complete and pass the pre-algebra algebra sequence. This program continues at UC Santa Cruz.
